data.title: 25 greatest football players of all time from the Grand Rapids area
data.meta_description: High school, college and pro careers were considered in the selection process
data.text:
The Grand Rapids-area list of 25 greatest football players of all time includes, clockwise from top left, Kirk Cousins, Gary Hogeboom, Joe Staley, George Andrie and Mitch Lyons.

One was a Purple People Eater, while another played on a defense named Doomsday.

Some played 80-to-100 years ago and others are playing on Sunday afternoons this fall.

MLive sports reporters across Michigan have identified the top 25 football players in their region, and the Grand Rapids guys are ranked below.

Grand Rapids considered only players who had Grand Rapids roots and had an impact at each level: high school, college and professional. Achievements, success and career longevity were all weighted in determining who made it and where they are ranked.

Check out the list and let us know in the comment section what you think

Let's begin our trip down memory lane:

25. PAUL GOEBEL, Grand Rapids Central

Paul Goebel (MLive File Photo)

Goebel played for Michigan from 1919-1922 and was a defensive end and receiver after graduating from Grand Rapids Central. He was an All-American in 1921 and a team captain in 1922. Goebel played professional football for the Columbus Tigers, the Chicago Bears and New York Yankees. Goebel became mayor of Grand Rapids in the 1950s.

24. MATT VANDERBEEK, West Ottawa

Matt VanderBeek (MLive File Photo)

VanderBeek was an all-state player at West Ottawa and went on to earn Big Ten honorable mention recognition his senior year at defensive end for Michigan State. VanderBeek played eight seasons in the NFL for Indianapolis, Minnesota, Dallas and Washington. He starred on Dallas’ special teams in 1993-1994 when the Cowboys won Super Bowl XXVIII.

23. CHARLES DESHANE, Creston

Charles DeShane is shown in this Grand Rapids Press photo with his chldren on July 24, 1986 (MLive File Photo)

DeShane was an All City quarterback at Creston in 1936 and 1937 and later quarterbacked the University of Alabama, earning All-Southeastern Conference honors his senior year. DeShane returned to coach Creston from 1942-1944 before embarking on a career with the Detroit Lions (1945-1949). He played quarterback and linebacker his first two seasons in Detroit and guard his final two years.

22. MIKE FRANCKOWIAK, West Catholic

Mike Franckowiak (MLive File Photo)

Franckowiak, who starred at West Catholic, quarterbacked Central Michigan to the 1974 NCAA Division II National Championship. The NFL was next. He played tight end, fullback and kicker during a four-year career with the Denver Broncos and Buffalo Bills.

21. ROGER ‘ROCKY’ ROSEMA, Central

Rocky Rosema speaks after being inducted in the 2003 Grand Rapids Sports Hall of Fame, during Thursday evening banquet ceremonies at the Van Andel Arena. GR Press photo/Noel Webley II

Rosema played high school football at Central before heading off to Ann Arbor to play defensive end and linebacker for Michigan from 1965-1967. The St. Louis Cardinals then came calling. Rosema played four seasons with the Cardinals from 1968-1971. He was inducted into the Grand Rapids Sports Hall of Fame in 2003.

20. KEVIN HARVERDINK, Hamilton

Handout

Haverdink’s NFL career was cut short after three seasons due to a back injury, but the Hamilton native’s achievements were memorable. Haverdink starred for the Hawkeyes in the early 1980s before graduating in 1984 after helping the basketball team win a state championship. But football was his game at Western Michigan, and his efforts helped him launch an NFL career. Haverdink, an offensive tackle, was drafted in the fifth round in 1989 by New Orleans. He played 41 games and started 27 for the Saints.

19. RON ESSINK, Zeeland

Ron Essink, left, played seven seasons with Seattle (MLive File Photo)

Essink, of Zeeland, became the first Grand Valley State University player drafted by the NFL when he was selected in the 10th round by the Seattle Seahawks in 1980. The offensive lineman played seven seasons with the Seahawks, including 1982 when Seattle advanced to the AFC championship game. Essink was a tight end at Zeeland High School and was a Division II All-American at Grand Valley.

18. MITCH LYONS, Forest Hills Northern

Steelers tight end Mitch Lyons recovers his own fumble as Tampa Bay's Greg Ballisari goes for ball. (PG Photo by Peter Diana 8/1/98)

Lyons is one of three Forest Hills Northern products to make the list. Lyons, who played tight end for the Spartans, was selected in the sixth round of the 1993 NFL Draft by Atlanta. He played four years in Atlanta and his final three seasons with Pittsburgh. Lyons had 39 career receptions and a touchdown.

17. TY HALLOCK, Greenville

It took three packers to bring down Detroit Lions Ty Hallock, formerly of Michigan State. Packers LeRoy Butler(36), Mike prior (45) and Keo Coleman (54) were all in on the tackle. Chronicle/Brian Masck

Hallock, a tight end, fullback and linebacker from Greenville, enjoyed an NFL career that spanned from 1993-2000, playing for the Detroit Lions, Jacksonville Jaguars and Chicago Bears. He played in 86 games and caught three touchdown passes. Hallock was an All Big Ten selection his senior season at Michigan State, and he now has two sons playing football at MSU.

16. JAY RIEMERSMA, Zeeland

#85 Jay Riemersma is grabbed by Jets #21 Victor Green during second quarter at Giants Stadium. 11/4/98 NJNP Photo/ Tim Farrell SL

Riemersma, of Zeeland, was a quarterback in high school and was recruited to play the position by Michigan. However, those plans ended due to a rotator cuff injury in 1994, and that turned out to be a break in the long run. The Wolverines moved him to tight end, and that’s what he played his final two seasons in Ann Arbor as well eight seasons in the NFL. Riemersma had 23 career touchdown receptions during his five years in Buffalo and two in Pittsburgh. He had 221 receptions for 2,524 yards in 112 games.

15. GARY HOGEBOOM, Northview

Gary Hogeboom - Dallas Cowboys quarterback - 9/26/80 file photo. BPN

From Northview High School to America's team, Hogeboom is recognized as one of Grand Rapids' top quarterbacks. Hogeboom earned MAC Most Valuable Player honors in 1979 after leading Central Michigan to a conference championship. Dallas drafted him in the fifth round in 1980, and he would play six seasons with the Cowboys, three with Indianapolis and one with Phoenix. Hogeboom threw for more than 9,400 career yards and 49 touchdowns in 10 NFL seasons.

14. CLARENCE ELLIS, Central

Clarence Ellis was featured in the Grand Rapids Press along with Grand Rapids native Mike Kadish on April 27, 1969 when both were playing for Notre Dame (Grand Rapids Press File Photo)

City League fans will remember Ellis for his athletic achievements in football and track during the late 1960s while competing at Central High School. Ellis would go on to star at Notre Dame as a defensive back from 1969-1971 where he earned consensus All-American honors. Ellis was drafted in the first round and 15th overall by Atlanta, and he played three seasons with the Falcons from 1972-74. He had eight career interceptions.

13. PAUL GRASMANIS, Jenison

Philadelphia nose tackle Paul Grasmanis of Jenison. (Chris Clark/THE GRAND RAPIDS PRESS)

Grasmanis, of Jenison, started three years at defensive end at Notre Dame, and it helped launch his NFL career. Grasmanis was drafted in the fourth round by the Chicago Bears, and he would play 10 years in the NFL with the Bears, Denver and Philadelphia. He was on the 2006 Philadelphia team that lost to New England in the Super Bowl. He had 151 tackles in 104 games, including 12 sacks.

12. ROBERT JACKSON, Allendale

Robert Jackson (MLive File Photo)

Jackson, who was an all-state player at Allendale, was a three-time All-MAC player at Central Michigan University who went on to play cornerback for seven seasons in the NFL. Cincinnati drafted Jackson in the 11th round in 1981, and he would intercept 15 passes and had seven fumble recoveries for the Bengals during his career, running two back for touchdowns. Jackson missed two seasons, and in both years, the Bengals were Super Bowl runner-up. He missed Super Bowl XVI due to injury, and he sat out the 1988 season due to a contract dispute.

11. JARED VELDHEER, Forest Hills Northern

Jared Veldheer is shown here with former Grand Rapids Press sports editor Bob Becker in 2003 during his high school days at Forest Hills Northern. (MLive File Photo)

The Forest Hills Northern graduate spent nine seasons in the NFL trenches before retiring this past March. Veldheer, an offensive lineman, was drafted in the third round by the Oakland Raiders in 2010, and he played four seasons in Oakland, four more in Arizona and last year in Denver, playing in 118 games and starting 113. Veldheer played college football at Hillsdale.

10. MIKE DUMAS, Lowell

Mike Dumas from Oct. 2, 1986 (MLive File Photo)

Dumas, of Lowell, played eight seasons as a big-hitting safety in the NFL with the Houston Oilers, Buffalo Bills, Jacksonville Jaguars and San Diego Chargers during the 1990s. Dumas was an all-state player for the Red Arrows before playing college football at Indiana. Dumas was selected in the second round by the Oilers. He finished his career with 292 tackles and seven interceptions.

9. MIKE KADISH, Catholic Central

Former NFL player Mike Kadish shows off the 1972 Super Bowl ring he got after his team, the Miami Dolphins, capped off a perfect season winning the national championship against the Washington Redskins, 14 to7, ( Rex Larsen photo ) BPN

How’s this for a two-year run? Kadish, a defensive tackle from Catholic Central, was an All-American at Notre Dame his senior season in 1971, and after being drafted in the first round by Miami, he was on the Dolphins' legendary 17-0 team that beat Washington in Super Bowl VII. Kadish played nine seasons in Buffalo, playing in 127 games.

8. JOEL SMEENGE, Hudsonville

Pittsburgh Steelers' Kordell Stewart scrambles out of the pocket in the second quarter chased by Jaguars' Joel Smeenge during their game in Jacksonville, Fla. Sunday Oct. 1, 2000. Stewart led the Steelers to a 24-13 win.(AP Photo/Scott Audette) AP

Smeenge, a defensive end, played 11 seasons in the NFL after starring at Hudsonville High School and Western Michigan University. Smeenge was drafted by the New Orleans Saints in the third round in 1990, and he played five seasons in the Big Easy. Smeenge then played five more years in Jacksonville. He played in 156 games and started 51, recording 225 tackles and 35.5 sacks.

7. DAVID HARRIS, Ottawa Hills

New York Jets defensive end Aaron Maybin (51) and New York Jets inside linebacker David Harris (52) punish Washington Redskins quarterback Rex Grossman (8) in the 4th quarter as the New York Jets defeat Washington Redskins, 34-19, in week 13 NFL action at FedEx Field in Landover, Md. (12/4/11) Andrew Mills/The Star-Ledger SL

Harris became one of the state’s top prospects while starring at linebacker for Ottawa Hills, and after leading the University of Michigan in tackles his junior and senior seasons, he was drafted in the second round in the 2007 draft by the New York Jets. Harris played 10 seasons for the Jets and one with New England before retiring after the 2017 season. He played in 164 NFL games and started 153, finishing with 1,109 tackles, including 723 solos.

6. KIRK COUSINS, Holland Christian

FILE - In this Aug. 9, 2019, file photo, Minnesota Vikings quarterback Kirk Cousins (8) drops back to pass in the first half of an NFL preseason football game against the New Orleans Saints, in New Orleans. Cousins has spoken several times this offseason about how much better he needs to perform in order to change the perception that he can't win a big game. Atlanta plays at Minnesota on Sunday, Sept. 8. (AP Photo/Bill Feig, File)

Cousins is in his eighth season in the NFL, having played his first six years in Washington before joining Minnesota. The veteran quarterback from Holland Christian High School was a three-year starter at Michigan State, having passed for over 9,100 yards and 66 touchdowns. Washington selected Cousins in the seventh round of the 2012 draft. Cousins has thrown for nearly 23,000 yards and 145 touchdowns in his NFL career.

5. RAY BENTLEY, Hudsonville

Ray Bentley (MLive File Photo)

Bentley was an all-state player at Hudsonville High School in 1978, and he would go on to find greatness in college, the USFL and the NFL. Bentley, a linebacker, was the MAC’s Most Valuable Player and Defensive Player of the Year in 1982, which launched a pro career that saw him play in two Super Bowls with the Buffalo Bills. Bentley also played in the USFL with the Michigan Panthers and the Oakland Invaders.

4. TERRY BARR, Central

Three Detroit players who deserve the lion’s share of the credit for 45-14 walloping of the Cardinals on Nov. 12, 1961 in St. Louis laugh it up after the game. They are (l-r) Nick Pietrosante, the leading ball carrier with 62 yards on 11 carries; Terry Barr, who scored one td on a 48-yard pass from Jim Ninowski; and Ninowski himself, who completed 11 of 27 passes, including two for tds. (AP Photo)

Barr played nine seasons with the Detroit Lions, beginning in 1957 when the team won its most recent National Football League championship. Barr, who played at Grand Rapids Central and the University of Michigan, was a flanker, halfback and defensive back. He caught 35 career touchdown passes with the Lions.

3. JOE STALEY, Rockford

San Francisco 49ers offensive tackle Joe Staley speaks to reporters at the team's football facility in Santa Clara, Calif., Monday, April 23, 2018. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

Staley, of Rockford, is in his 13th season with the San Francisco 49ers this fall. The 6-foot-6, 295-pound offensive tackle is a six-time Pro Bowl player who was drafted 28th overall by the 49ers in the 2007 draft. Staley starred at Rockford and later Central Michigan University.

2. BOB LURTSEMA, Ottawa Hills

Lurtsema, a lineman, was part of the Minnesota Vikings Purple People Eaters defense during the 1970s, and he played in Super Bowls VIII and IX. Lurtsema, who starred at Ottawa Hills and Western Michigan, played 12 seasons in the NFL for the Baltimore Colts, New York Giants and Seattle Seahawks in addition to the Vikings. He played in 144 games and started 81.

1. GEORGE ANDRIE, Catholic Central

Dallas Cowboys defensive end George Andrie picks up a Bart Starr fumble and is about to follow teammate Jethro Pugh (75) into the end zone to score in the NFL Championship game against the Green Bay Packers, Dec. 31, 1967. This game took place in Green Bay, Wis. Played in sub-zero temperatures the contest was later dubbed 'The Ice Bowl.' (AP Photo/files) ASSOCIATED PRESS

Andrie starred at Catholic Central before graduating in 1958. He later played at Marquette University, followed by 11 seasons with the Dallas Cowboys. Andrie, a defensive end on Dallas' Doomsday Defense, was a Super Bowl champion in 1972 and a five-time Pro Bowl selection. Andrie's career highlights include scoring a touchdown in the 1967 NFL Championship Game at Green Bay, which is dubbed the Ice Bowl after temperatures dropped to 15-degrees below zero. He played in 141 games, started 137 and finished his career with 97 sacks. Andrie died on Aug. 21, 2018, in Woodway Tex.

MORE

Here are the other 25 greatest players lists from MLive regional sites:
